qas.question: What is the sort of circular imperfection in a piece of wood called?
What property of wood does a knot usually reduce in the wood around it?
In what direction is wood often sawn so that a knot appears as a solid circle that the grain flows around?
Are knots usually lighter or darker than the surrounding wood?
The direction of grain in a knot can differ by as much as how many degrees from the regular wood?

context: A <a0_0>knot<a0_0/> is a particular type of imperfection in a piece of wood; it will affect the technical properties of the wood, usually reducing the local <a1_0>strength<a1_0/> and increasing the tendency for splitting along the wood grain, but may be exploited for visual effect. In a <a2_0>longitudinally<a2_0/> sawn plank, a knot will appear as a roughly circular "solid" (usually <a3_0>darker<a3_0/>) piece of wood around which the grain of the rest of the wood "flows" (parts and rejoins). Within a knot, the direction of the wood (grain direction) is up to <a4_0>90<a4_0/> degrees different from the grain direction of the regular wood.
